issue.title: Bitcoind as system background service
issue.body:
When using bitcoind as a wallet-less full node, it would be useful to be able to run it as a system service, so that it starts automatically at startup and can be controlled though the OS's normal service start and stop functionality.

For the Debian/Ubuntu side of things see hippich and fungus' posts here: https://bitcointalk.org/?topic=965.0 . It'd make most sense to integrate this into the PPA. There are two different systems in use here: old-style sysv init scripts, and upstart.

For Windows/OSX I'm not sure what is necessary. At least we'd need new installer packages, separate from the normal "Bitcoin Core Wallet" which provide a node and nothing more.

The installer would also need to create user credentials to run under.

Edit: for the service install, this would also imply moving the configuration to a system-wide instead of user location, for example `/etc/bitcoin.conf` as well as default the data directory to a system-scope location (probably `/var/lib/bitcoin`).

events.body:
Yes, we need this.

It would also mean the blockchain database can become shared and system-wide, and be stored in /var/lib/bitcoin or something, instead of in home directories (which seems frowned upon, for such amounts of data).
Yes, sounds like a good plan. As we don't have to worry about the wallet here, everything can be public and shared.
@drak You do realize that calling something 'trivial' is the same as volunteering to implement it?

I've just introduced this to Alpine Linux. The bitcoin daemon runs under /var/lib/bitcoin as bitcoin:bitcoin using /etc/bitcoin.conf for configuration. The post install script generates a random user / pass / port for a new installation. The init script also enforces sensible permissions.

Via LXC 1.00+ it is possible to run an unprivileged Alpine container on any Linux (size 5mb)

Same is possible for namecoin
Hopefully you did not do what the debian package did at one point and use a non-cryptographic PRNG to pick those keys, making it trivial to guess the rpc credentials?
do you consider /dev/urandom strong enough ?
Sure, but its how you use it that counts. Link me to the code and I'll review it.

It's the 2nd from last addition at http://lists.alpinelinux.org/alpine-devel/3710.html

User is 32 char & Pass is 64 char

@itoffshore Cool. Characters which need to be escaped in URLs break some applications, I'd recommend leaving out the symbols. The ones Bitcoin itself generates are just a base58 encoded 256-bit value. (I believe I've seen % and & both cause problems, ! is sometimes annoying if specifying the strings on the command line). Looks fine generally, the lack of error handling (e.g. /dev/urandom couldn't be opened, or something doesn't support the -c extension to head) might be concerning but bitcoin won't let you run with a too short rpcpassword.  Sorry for the diversion. :)
`/dev/urandom` doesn't block (`/dev/random` does block if there is not enough entropy) - as Alpine uses Busybox the command should work everywhere.

issue.title: New Page: Describe How To Run A Full Node
issue.body:
As requested by Raúl Martínez and supported by @wladimir, add a page for advanced users describing how to install bitcoind as a system service and configure it (and your network) so it can act as a full peer.

I tried writing an outline for this page, but it quickly became evident that starting bitcoind as a service on Linux requires a fair amount of extra work and a lot of "if you have X, then do Y"-type descriptions covering the different ways different distributions handle init scripts.

I think it may be advantageous to delay writing this page until there's a package for Ubuntu, Windows, or OSX which lets bitcoind run as a background service.  See: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/4124

events.body: The system service would concern a wallet-less build, so generating a safe rpcuser/pass is not of critical importance (and given that RPC listens on localhost only...).
@drak have you got it working?  I've tried registering as a windows service via sc. exe create but no luck.

[Alpine Linux](http://http://alpinelinux.org/) has packages now for Bitcoin / Namecoin with both running as a service as Bitcoin / Namecoin user:groups. There are templates in [LXC](https://linuxcontainers.org/) for Alpine (a running Alpine container is 5 meg in size) so it is simple to run Bitcoin on any Linux (or as a virtualbox service in Windows).

issue.title: -datadir is now allowed in config files
Added systemd .service file in order to help distributions integrate bitcoind
issue.body: Providing this .service file might be used as a guide by packagers and helps lowering the bar.

events.body: There is also a PR with Upstart and OpenRC support #4611

This (and PR #4611) is some nice work. Is there any (official) effort to make an Ubuntu (or other distro) package that includes it?

(Edit: I've seen the existing PPA repository and the current bitcoin package does not include any init scripts)

On any Linux distribution install [LXC](https://linuxcontainers.org/) (Ubuntu / Debian / Redhat / Archlinux / OpenSUSE have packages) & create an [Alpine Linux container](http://wiki.alpinelinux.org/wiki/LXC) (this is 5 meg in size).

Log in to the container (user = root & password is empty) & run:

```
apk add bitcoin
rc-update add bitcoin default
rc-service bitcoin start
```

& bitcoin will run as user bitcoin. There is also a package for namecoin in Alpine.

For extra security & complete isolation run an [unprivileged container](http://www.stgraber.org/2014/01/17/lxc-1-0-unprivileged-containers/).

[Ubuntu docs for LXC](https://help.ubuntu.com/12.04/serverguide/lxc.html)

issue.title: Update Debian (Ubuntu) package with bitcoind init scripts
issue.body:
Given Issue #4124 (bitcoind as system service) and now that PR #4611 (init scripts and docs for Upstart and OpenRC) is merged, it would be nice to see some updates to the Debian packaging (in `contrib/debian`, right?) to properly install `bitcoind` as a system service.

It would also be nice to see better documentation on the Debian/Ubuntu package:
- Where it lives (source and binary)
- Better build instructions
- etc

(I've done a little bit of work in this area on my own, but am an Debian/Ubuntu newb. I'm definitely willing to help with testing and documentation.)

References:
- [Debian contrib directory](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/master/contrib/debian)
- [Bitcoin LaunchPad page](https://launchpad.net/~bitcoin/+archive/ubuntu/bitcoin)

events.body: Nice work. Would love to see a package for Litecoin too.

issue.title: Installation scripts for daemon mode on Ubuntu using Upstart (resubmission)
issue.body:
Contains configuration files and an installation script for setting up Master Core (`bitcoind`) in daemon mode on Ubuntu using the Upstart init daemon. This is part of the work necessary to implement Issue #131, but does not address the actual packaging.

Some of the files are from the current [upstream](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin) `master` branch. The files in `contrib/msc-ubuntu` were created specifically for Master Core (a README and a default `bitcoin.conf` file for Master Core)

Here are some of the merged upstream PR's included in this "back-port" to Master Core.
- [bitcoin #4611](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/4611)
- [bitcoin #4577](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/4577)

Upstream issues:
- [bitcoin #4124](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/4124)

Note: This is a resubmitted PR, the original PR was #129. This PR is now based off of the `mscore-0.0.8` branch and includes a [change](https://github.com/msgilligan/mastercore/commit/440f19274d63b5dfe2599ac5f88b40bc42209aa7) suggested by @dexX7.

issue.title: Setup of a full node should be automated
issue.body:
The how-to guide for setting up a full node is nice, but every step after the "apt-get install bitcoind" can and should be automated, either in the official ppa or a separate one:
- Create locked account
- Create directory structure
- Create bitcoin.conf with random password and correct permissions
- Configure logging to /var/log
- Set up log rotation (this is not mentioned in the guide, but should be)
- Create init.d or upstart file (ask user if the service should be configured to autostart)

Bonus points for setting up an AppArmor profile to improve security and autodetecting Tor running on the same machine. The tor package can probably be used as a template - it includes logrotate and AppArmor.

events.body: This is sufficiently done now (`doc/init.md`), thanks everyone, closing the issue
What about running it as a service on Microsoft Windows? This doesn't seem to have been addressed.
We don't have any active windows developers, so none of us will do that. But feel free to write a guide on that.
